quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, then you shouldn't be designing the product.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Sets a high bar for product craft: designers should constantly identify improvement opportunities rather than settling.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In the long run, the measure of our success will be the amount of value that we create for customers, and you can put effort into demonstrating that you have created this value and stuff like that, but there's no substitute for actually having created it.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A clear customer-value metric that warns against confusing marketing/proof with real delivered value.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It became an assumption that it should always be trying to remove friction when the challenge is really comprehension.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Contrarian reframing: the real UX bottleneck is often understanding, not clicks or steps.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If people could get over the idea of reducing friction as a number of goal or reducing the number of clicks or taps to do something, and instead focus on how can I make this simple? How do I prevent people from having to think in order to use my software?
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: optimize for simplicity and cognitive load reduction rather than superficial friction metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The decision is about have you exhausted the possibilities? Creating the distance so that you can make an intellectual rational decision about it rather than an emotional decision is essential. And the reason I say you have to be coldly rational about it is because it's fucking humiliating.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A pivoting decision framework emphasizing exhaustive exploration and emotional detachment to counter bias and ego.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building software for enterprises, you've probably felt the pain of integrating single sign-on, SCIM, RBAC, audit logs, and other features required by big customers.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Calls out the concrete “enterprise readiness” checklist that commonly blocks B2B deals, useful for prioritizing product infrastructure work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: WorkOS turns those deal blockers into drop-in APIs with a modern developer platform built specifically for B2B SaaS.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Frames a practical build-vs-buy approach: convert enterprise feature requirements into modular integrations rather than bespoke implementations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They're essentially Stripe for enterprise features.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Memorable analogy that provides a mental model for positioning and evaluating an “infrastructure API” vendor category.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Metronome, you hand it all off to the real-time billing infrastructure that just works.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to treat billing as core infrastructure (especially for usage-based pricing) rather than ad hoc glue code and spreadsheets.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Metronome turns raw usage events into accurate invoices, gives customers bills they actually understand and keeps every team in sync in real-time.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor
quotes.context: A concrete operational model for usage-based billing: event ingestion → invoicing → customer clarity → cross-team real-time alignment.

quotes.topic_title: What Stewart is doing after Slack
quotes.text: I'm mostly just chilling. I left Salesforce two and a half years ago and I have a two and a half year old, so she was actually born three days after my last day, so a lot of time with family and it's an enormous privilege to be able to spend time with young kids while they're young.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A concrete example of intentionally prioritizing family and time allocation after a major career transition.

quotes.topic_title: What Stewart is doing after Slack
quotes.text: Basically every three to six weeks there's this cycle because Cal Henderson who's the CTO of Slack and who also, we worked together on Flickr, so have worked together now for 23 years, have been talking about what we want to do next if there is something.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable cadence for exploring new ideas with a long-term collaborator, grounded in a specific time cycle and relationship duration.

quotes.topic_title: What Stewart is doing after Slack
quotes.text: But honestly, the big challenge has been I think these things are destroying the world and what we're good at is making software.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A contrarian reflection on the moral tension of building software amid concerns about tech’s societal impact.

quotes.topic_title: What Stewart is doing after Slack
quotes.text: So you find some way to make software that helped people use their phones less often, then that would be a big winner, but haven't come up with anything good.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Actionable product direction: build tools that reduce phone usage—paired with the honest admission that it’s hard to execute well.

quotes.topic_title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
quotes.text: This is pretty easy because it's a very familiar S-curve where you have, it's flat and it starts arcing up and then there's a really steep part and then it levels off again. And on the horizontal axis, you can think of cost or effort and on the vertical axis, it's value or convenience.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Defines the utility-curve mental model teams can use to map effort to user value when prioritizing product work.

quotes.topic_title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
quotes.text: the idea is the first bit of effort you put into something doesn't result in a huge amount of value. And then there's some magic threshold where it produces an enormous amount of value and then continued investment doesn't really pay off.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Explains the key dynamic behind why some features feel worthless until they cross a usability threshold, then hit diminishing returns.

quotes.topic_title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
quotes.text: The reason I felt like this was so important is because we would talk about a feature, and usually features are thought of as a binary. You either have this feature or you don't. The argument I guess was have we just not invested enough in this or have we got all the value or convenience or quality or whatever that we could get out of this?
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Challenges the common “feature shipped = done” mindset and reframes prioritization as deciding whether to invest to reach the steep part of the curve or stop.

quotes.topic_title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
quotes.text: We would try to really investigate and decide whether we were on the first shallow part of the curve, the second shallow part of the curve, or we're just coming up to it.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for diagnosing whether a feature needs more investment, is near breakthrough, or is already past the point of diminishing returns.

quotes.topic_title: Utility curves for prioritizing product investment
quotes.text: The line actually moves because once people are familiar with a piece of software or the way a feature is implemented or something like that, their standards go up, and so there's this competition.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Adds a dynamic layer to the model: user expectations rise over time, so “good enough” quality thresholds shift and require ongoing investment.

quotes.topic_title: Rising quality bars and neglected UX basics
quotes.text: When you hit the option to set the time zone on an event in Google Calendar, on the iOS app, it presents all the time zones in the world in alphabetical order. And I mean, there's probably worse orderings, but there's no value in that.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A concrete example of high-impact UX debt: a common flow optimized for an arbitrary ordering rather than user intent.

quotes.topic_title: Rising quality bars and neglected UX basics
quotes.text: This is an app that's used by at least hundreds of millions of people, presumably every single Google employee. It's bananas how bad it is.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Highlights that even world-class teams can ship glaring UX issues, implying basics require continual attention regardless of scale.

quotes.topic_title: Rising quality bars and neglected UX basics
quotes.text: there's a real value in delighting customers and there's an emotional connection that they form or don't form. And in some cases that could be really positive like they would recommend it.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Frames delight as a driver of advocacy via emotional connection, not just “nice-to-have” polish.

quotes.topic_title: Rising quality bars and neglected UX basics
quotes.text: there's this category of really essential parts of the app again like account creation, sign up, forgot password, things like that, that for most organizations very infrequently get a lot of love and iteration and improvement despite the fact that the quality bar has gone up across the board and continually goes up.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to keep iterating on unglamorous, high-frequency basics because user expectations continuously rise.

quotes.topic_title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
quotes.text: But you can definitely practice and you can definitely get better.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Reframes “taste” as a learnable skill teams can deliberately improve through repetition and training.

quotes.topic_title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
quotes.text: The second thing I'd say is you can create a real advantage for yourself, for your product, for your company by leaning into it because most people don't have good taste and don't invest.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Positions craft/taste investment as a durable competitive advantage precisely because many teams underinvest in it.

quotes.topic_title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
quotes.text: We noticed how few people would move their umbrella out of the way.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Sets up the “tilt your umbrella” metaphor for empathy and small courtesies that shape user experience.

quotes.topic_title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
quotes.text: And so we would say it's not like tilting your umbrella is our opportunity. That's not a great rephrase of your margin is my opportunity, but your failure to really be consider it exercise this courtesy and really be empathic about other people's experience is an advantage that you can create a critical advantage.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A practical mental model: competitors’ lack of empathy and attention to small UX courtesies can be your wedge.

quotes.topic_title: Taste, empathy, and Slack’s craft advantage
quotes.text: it wouldn't have grown the way it did without those little conveniences which caused people to form an emotional connection because a lot of our growth came from startup A uses Slack, and then someone leaves startup A for startup B, and startup B doesn't use Slack yet. And they would be like, "Oh my God, you guys, you really, this is so good. We got to try it." And the spread was driven by that and people really genuinely advocating for it.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Concrete growth mechanism: “little conveniences” create emotional connection that drives word-of-mouth via job-switching users.

quotes.topic_title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
quotes.text: Why did we ask people for email address and password if their ownership of the email address was the thing that allowed them to create the account in the first place? Why don't we just ask them for their email address and then send them a link?
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A simple reframing of what “authentication” really needs, leading to a lower-friction signup/login flow.

quotes.topic_title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
quotes.text: Typing your password on your phone if you have any minimal threshold of password hygiene is a terrible experience.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete UX pain point that justifies investing in alternative login mechanisms on mobile.

quotes.topic_title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
quotes.text: We reluctantly decided that we had to send notifications for every single message as the default for new accounts.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A counterintuitive onboarding choice: match users’ prior expectations first, even if it’s not the long-term ideal default.

quotes.topic_title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
quotes.text: But we realized it was worth that investment to get people over the hump.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A memorable product principle: spend effort to help users cross the initial comprehension/adoption barrier.

quotes.topic_title: Early Slack craft decisions that paid off
quotes.text: As soon as someone does it, everyone's like, "Okay, I'm going to do that too for my message."
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A practical warning about social dynamics: priority/attention-grabbing features tend to get abused and lose meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
quotes.text: And it became really obnoxious and people would complain about it, but it was, I don't know, I guess tragedy of the commons.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Frames abusive @everyone usage as a classic incentive problem where individual benefit degrades the shared communication environment.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
quotes.text: Hey, this is going to cause a notification for 147 people in eight different time zones. Are you sure you want to send this message with the @everyone?
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A concrete example of making the “cost” of an action salient at the moment of use to nudge behavior without removing the feature.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
quotes.text: And of course, that worked amazingly and it dropped off.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Highlights that lightweight UX interventions can dramatically reduce harmful behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
quotes.text: Yeah, that survived and good because it was a trivially easy thing to implement and made a really big difference.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Emphasizes high-leverage product work: small implementation effort can yield outsized cultural and behavioral impact.

quotes.topic_title: Shaping behavior: @everyone rooster and norms
quotes.text: But it also taught people how the product worked, because people probably didn't know that @everyone or @channel... Didn't think about the cost, at least.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Shows how guardrails can double as education, improving user mental models while preventing misuse.

quotes.topic_title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
quotes.text: And so we couldn't just deploy it right away. We realized that some of the decision-makers, the owners of the organizations were going to have really strong opinions about this. We also realized that some of the end users are going to have strong opinions, and we wanted to figure out a way to balance the concerns and give people appropriate means of control.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Highlights the rollout mental model of anticipating stakeholder conflict and designing explicit control surfaces for both admins and end users.

quotes.topic_title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
quotes.text: So we came up with this really elaborate system for the rollout, which was, we told everyone, I'm sorry, every Slack administrator that this was coming weeks before it came.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Emphasizes pre-communication to admins as a key operational step when shipping workflow-impacting features at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
quotes.text: And it wasn't to create this dynamic where people were at war, but so that you could change a policy and then people could still customize and stuff like that.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Captures a governance framework: layered overrides that allow org policy changes without permanently removing individual autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
quotes.text: And I think critically, with setting a bunch of defaults, because if we didn't set the default, most people wouldn't turn it on at all. If we didn't default you to Do Not Disturb from 8:00 P.M. to 8:00 A.M. you probably, if you're the average person, wouldn't ever do it yourself.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A concrete example of why sensible defaults drive adoption for beneficial features that users won’t proactively configure.

quotes.topic_title: Rolling out Do Not Disturb at scale
quotes.text: But this was a much longer and more convoluted process, but it allowed the millions of people who were using Slack to get the feature without creating a bunch of conflict and without people turning it off automatically.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Shows the tradeoff: investing in a complex rollout can reduce backlash and prevent users from disabling the feature.

quotes.topic_title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
quotes.text: And so the problem there is comprehension, and this will come up an enormous amount.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Reframes the common “reduce friction” mantra by naming comprehension as the dominant bottleneck in many product experiences.

quotes.topic_title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
quotes.text: So look, I really want to get these tickets. I know exactly what they are. They're Taylor Swift tickets for this date at this venue. And so in that scenario, it doesn't really matter if Ticketmaster's website is slow, it doesn't really matter if the payments page errors out, you're going to persist and get through it.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Uses a high-intent example to show why friction reduction has diminishing returns when intent and specificity are maxed out.

quotes.topic_title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
quotes.text: What we had to worry about was creating comprehension and in two senses, what is this thing? And what am I supposed to do next?
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Provides a practical two-part comprehension checklist teams can apply to onboarding, landing pages, and core flows.

quotes.topic_title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
quotes.text: They're like, "I want to get people who come to my webpage to the sign up form as quickly as possible." But if they don't know what they're signing up for and they don't know what it's going to do after, is it going to spam them? They don't know, "Am I going to have to pay on the next step or what?" Then they're just going to back out.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Counterintuitively argues that optimizing for fewer steps can reduce conversion when users lack clarity and trust about what happens next.

quotes.topic_title: Friction vs comprehension: don’t optimize clicks
quotes.text: Again, it really makes a difference in those cases where people do have an intent and they do know what they're trying to do is a poor approach when the challenge is really comprehension, and I think the secret is most, 70%, 80% or whatever of a product design is in that comprehension step
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: Offers a memorable rule-of-thumb that most product design work is about helping users understand, not just removing friction.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
quotes.text: Stop what you're doing for a second. Close your eyes, take a couple of deep breaths, and then pretend that you're an actual human being. And open their eyes again, and then look at this thing and see, can you figure out what it's supposed to do or say. Or what action you're supposed to take or what the impact will be if you take that action.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A practical empathy check you can run on any UI/flow to reveal confusing design and unclear calls-to-action.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
quotes.text: I said, "Oh God, yeah. I try to instill this into the rest of the team, but certainly I feel like what we have right now is just a giant piece of shit. It's just terrible and we should be humiliated that we offer this to the public. Not everyone finds that motivational though."
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A memorable example of using extreme candor to set a high bar and normalize relentless improvement.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
quotes.text: But in the aggregate, if you can't see almost limitless opportunities to improve, then you shouldn't be designing the product, or you shouldn't be in charge of the company, or you shouldn't almost nothing.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A demanding standard for product leadership: always be able to identify meaningful improvements, even when things are “good.”

quotes.topic_title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
quotes.text: Every time he messed up, he wanted the ski instructor to tell him exactly what he was doing wrong. Because to him, every one of those was a gem that he could collect, and he could actually become a good skier.
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A learning model that reframes mistakes as valuable “gems,” encouraging teams to seek precise critique rather than avoid it.

quotes.topic_title: Relentless critique culture and continuous improvement
quotes.text: But if you can get to the point where like, "Hey, we are trying to find improvements. We're trying to be critical because you're trying to make this as great as it can possibly be."
quotes.speaker: Stewart Butterfield
quotes.context: A trust-building framing for critique culture that makes direct feedback feel aligned with a shared goal, not personal attack.

quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a practical starting-point heuristic: use tools that remove the “blank page” barrier when you have an idea but lack implementation clarity.

quotes.text: Lovable lets you build working apps and websites by simply chatting with AI.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Offers a concrete methodology shift—using conversational iteration as the interface for prototyping and building software.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's perfect for marketers, spinning up tools, product managers prototyping new ideas, and founders launching their next business.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
